HEADLINE: Bill Paves Way For Third Term For Bloomberg

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN; Sewell Chan, Jonathan P. Hicks and Jennifer Medina contributed reporting.

 BODY:
City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said on Thursday that legislation to alter the city's term limits law would be introduced on Tuesday, paving the way for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Ms. Quinn and more than 40 other elected officials to stay in office four more years.
 The Council's vote on the measure -- which Mr. Bloomberg has pushed for behind the scenes -- could come later this month, Ms. Quinn told reporters at a news conference. And while she declined to reveal her position on the legislation, she said she would meet with other members of the Council to discuss the bill and ''move forward in the process after that.''
 Ms. Quinn's remarks came on a dramatic day at City Hall, as Mr. Bloomberg for the first time explained why he wanted to run for another term. Her comments, and the rapid timetable she described, immediately set off criticism that a deal had already been struck between the mayor and Ms. Quinn, who has been his close ally, to overhaul the term limits law, which restricts citywide elected officials to two four-year terms. 
 Voters have twice approved the term limits, and Ms. Quinn had previously said she was opposed to undoing the voters' will. 
 Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat who represents Brooklyn and Queens, and City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., who both plan to run for mayor next year, denounced the plan to extend term limits as a subversion of democracy.
 ''This is fundamentally about a back-room deal, substituting the value and judgment of the citizens of New York City for their own,'' Mr. Weiner said during a news conference just outside the gates of City Hall. ''This is the quintessential inside deal between two ends of City Hall.''
 Mayor Bloomberg, at a formal news conference in the Blue Room at City Hall, said that the economic crisis facing the city presents challenges more grave than those New York confronted in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
 ''Given the events of recent weeks and given the enormous challenges we face, I don't want to walk away from a city I feel I can help lead through these tough times,'' said Mr. Bloomberg, a billionaire businessman.
 Still, although the mayor repeatedly pointed to the Wall Street crisis as the driving reason for his decision to overhaul the law and seek another term, it was clear that he began considering the idea and reaching out to potential supporters well before the financial tumult began last month.
 Mr. Bloomberg said at the news conference that he was still a supporter of term limits, but that he had come to believe that three terms should be the limit. Later in the day, responding to a reporter's question, he said he would not seek any change in the future that would allow him to run for a fourth term.
 Mr. Bloomberg also spoke expansively about his love of a job he has long called the greatest in the world.
 ''I think that we have come a long ways and I think that we have more to do and that we can do it,'' he said. ''It's not that anybody is indispensable; it is that people have put so much into this, have taken us in the right direction -- schools, crime, the economy, cultural institutions, parks, openness and accountability -- and every time I look around, I think there's so much more we can do.''
 Since word leaked on Tuesday that Mr. Bloomberg had decided to pursue a third term, the city's political establishment has been struggling to gauge the potential ripple effects on civic life in general, and next year's citywide elections in particular.
 The legislation the mayor backs would extend term limits to three four-year terms from two for all citywide elected officials -- mayor, comptroller and public advocate -- as well as the five borough presidents and the 51-member City Council.
 But beyond that, supporters and opponents alike have been somewhat thrown by the lack of details about the bill. For example, while the cosmetics heir Ronald S. Lauder, a former champion of term limits who now backs another term for Mr. Bloomberg, has said that any extension of term limits should be temporary, Ms. Quinn said on Thursday that the Council would make the change permanent. 
 And while Mr. Bloomberg has insisted that city officials do not have time to hold a referendum on the issue, others say a special election could easily be scheduled to allow voters to be heard.
 Ms. Quinn, who had been expected to run for mayor next year, said she would instead run for re-election to her Council seat and the speakership if the term limit law was amended. She acknowledged that she had retreated from her previous -- and adamant -- opposition to any changes in the 15-year-old law.
 ''I did take a position last December that indicated I wasn't open to making a change in term limits, and obviously there is the potential that that might change,'' she said. ''If that does happen, that will be a change in position.''
 When asked whether she had been promised anything by Mr. Bloomberg in exchange for her support for extending term limits, Ms. Quinn looked incredulous and said: ''Promised by the mayor? Nothing.''
 While many council members say privately that the mayor has the votes to pass the bill, they caution that such support could erode -- especially if members hear from irate constituents. Indeed, some early public reaction in polls, on Web sites and in letters to newspapers has been negative, with some people comparing what they see as a power grab to moves by foreign leaders like Vladimir Putin of Russia and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. Still, Mr. Bloomberg remains broadly popular, and his appeal may override public distaste with the way he and council members are moving to change the law.
 Another wild card is what the city's potent unions will do. Some labor leaders say privately that they are adopting a cautious attitude, uncomfortable with what they see as an undermining of voters' will, yet afraid of crossing a mayor who has enormous say over contracts and policies.
 One powerful union leader, Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said she was uncertain about what steps, if any, the union would take to oppose the mayor's efforts to extend term limits.
 ''I am going to have a real discussion with our members, and I wish that there would be a real discussion in the city,'' Ms. Weingarten said. ''This is a significant policy change, and there has been no real public airing of the debate. We live in a unprecedented world right now, and we have to explore the pros and cons of changing, and of doing it in this kind of way, rather than putting it to the voters.''
 If re-elected, Mr. Bloomberg, a longtime Democrat who became a Republican to run for mayor in 2001 but declared himself an independent last year, would be only the fourth mayor in the city's modern history to serve a third term.
 He said it was too early to determine what party banner, if any, he would run under. 
 ''This is not the time for politics,'' he told reporters.
 But people close to the mayor say he is likely to run as an independent.
 During his 28-minute news conference, Mr. Bloomberg appeared more tense and rigid than usual, rarely offering his trademark wisecracks or playful banter with reporters. His top lieutenants, including three deputy mayors who had opposed a third term, stood off to the side, stone-faced. A few of Mr. Bloomberg's commissioners attended, also betraying little emotion.
 Mr. Bloomberg said he was not deterred by what people have long called the curse of the third term, in which popular mayors or governors stumble badly in their last stanza. In fact, he said that he relished a challenge, and suggested that if the first two terms were any indication, the third might be the most satisfying.
 ''The bottom line is, we face some tough times, and I'd be honored to run again, and if the voters want me again, I'd be honored to serve,'' he said. ''This is just giving them the option.''

HEADLINE: To Run or Not to Run Again? Mayor's Ego May Have Provided Answer

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BARBARO

 BODY:
In early 2008, Michael R. Bloomberg began calling his friends for career advice. His flirtation with a presidential bid had just ended, and New York City's term limits law would eventually force him from office. For the first time in years, he was at a loss for what to do next. 
 A longtime adviser suggested the ''Bill Gates type of life'' -- a state of semi-retirement filled with charitable works and worldwide travel. 
 But Mr. Bloomberg chafed at the idea. ''He wanted to be mayor much more,'' this person said. ''He is a linear guy. He likes a clear job description.'' 
 Mr. Bloomberg contends that an unexpected economic crisis motivated his quest to seek a third term as mayor and revise the city's term limits -- a position that reverses himself, the law, and to many people's minds, the will of the voters, who twice approved the restrictions. 
 But it is clear, from interviews with the mayor's friends and advisers, that there is another powerful force at play: Mr. Bloomberg's ego.
 Ego, of course, can be an animating, even necessary thing for any politician. And there were certainly people ready to feed Mr. Bloomberg's.
 Influential business leaders like Steven Rattner, the financier, and Richard D. Parsons, the former chief executive of Time Warner, strongly pressed Mr. Bloomberg to try to remain in office, telling him that the depth of the financial troubles required his talents and temperament.
 ''We are in an extraordinary period of time, which will be followed by economic consequences that are totally unpredictable,'' said the developer Jerry I. Speyer, when asked why he urged the mayor to run again. 
 And financial crisis aside, those close to Mr. Bloomberg have said that he has come to love almost every aspect of being mayor -- from the actual civic achievements, to the considerable celebrity.
 Two hours before he announced his third-term ambitions at City Hall on Thursday, Mr. Bloomberg attended a packed breakfast of small-business people in Queens, who crowned him the king of that borough. (In an apt moment of political theater, the event's organizers hired a trumpeter, dressed in full Renaissance costume, to play for his mock coronation.)
 At the event, Mr. Bloomberg smiled through 30 minutes of photographs with fellow award winners and then eagerly worked the room, telling jokes and slapping backs. (''People get more religion during a downturn,'' he told a minister.) 
 Mr. Bloomberg was rewarded with calls of ''Four more years!'' and ''Go for a third term!''
 The mayor's closest friends said that he so relishes his job, from the small-bore borough breakfasts to the billion-dollar development projects, that he finds the prospect of just about anything else wanting. 
 Most jobs ''would never fully engage him,'' said Mortimer Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News and a friend of Mr. Bloomberg. He added, ''I think he would waste away if he were in a state of semi-activity.'' 
 ''The one thing you can say about the mayoralty of New York City is that it's a full-time job,'' Mr. Zuckerman said. 
 So, of course, is being president of the United States, and governor of New York, options that Mr. Bloomberg and his political advisers considered seriously over the last two years, as they gamed out a life after City Hall. 
 Mr. Bloomberg ultimately decided that a third-party candidacy would not be viable, or perhaps even necessary.
 And Mr. Bloomberg lacked enthusiasm for taking on the challenges of Albany's political culture -- let alone for commuting two hours each way to the capital several times a week.
 Overseeing the new Bloomberg charitable foundation loomed as an option, but Mr. Bloomberg had already said that role would fall to his deputy mayor, Patricia E. Harris. And, as one friend said, philanthropy is the final job Mr. Bloomberg wants in life, not the next one. ''It's a pretty sedate life,'' this person said. 
 That left a third term as mayor, which he debated with advisers for months. ''Everybody called it the mayor's Hamlet routine -- to run or not to run,'' said Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the Partnership for New York City, a business group whose board includes many of Mr. Bloomberg's friends in the business world. 
 Mr. Bloomberg was already leaning toward challenging term limits to remain in office when the full dimensions of the financial crisis erupted -- having started as a housing market downturn largely outside New York City, and then having snowballed into a meltdown that reached deep into the canyons of Lower Manhattan. 
 The city's business titans began to lean harder on him. And, those close to him say, he began to hear similar sentiments -- from dozens of voters on the subway and during his neighborhood tours. It was the affirmation, his aides said, that helped him make a decision to run again, which he characterized on Thursday in terms of public service.
 ''There is no greater honor than being able to make a difference in people's lives and for me that's what public service really is all about,'' he said at City Hall. 
 But those opposed to the move see plenty of pride -- and hubris. ''Democracy is bigger than any one person,'' said the city's comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., who has been planning a 2009 mayoral run.
 Mr. Speyer, the developer, said that regardless of the debate on term limits, the mayor's decision to run again should be viewed as an act of selflessness. ''He could go off and do anything he wants,'' Mr. Speyer said. ''He could go to the proverbial island and do nothing. He could run a foundation and gives tons of money away, become the head of a university, go back into business.'' 
 Instead, Mr. Speyer said, he wants to be mayor. 
 ''There isn't a person on the face of the earth that does not have some ego,'' he said. ''But if you look at the job of being mayor, especially at a time like the period we have entered, it's quite unusual for a person like Mike to be willing to say he would do this for another four years.''
 Whatever the exact balance of ego and obligation behind Mr. Bloomberg's decision to seek another term, he was not shy about his sense of what he could do.
 ''I think our second term was better than our first term, in terms of coming up with new things and really making a difference in this city,'' he said at the news conference announcing his plans. ''And if I get the opportunity to present myself to the voters a year from November, and if they want more of it, I see no reason why a third term couldn't even be better.''

HEADLINE: Teams With Deep Pockets Could Be In Too Deep

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON. 
E-mail: hjaraton@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The next president of the United States could serve consecutive terms, and when his eight-year administration concluded, Alex Rodriguez would still be a Yankee.
 He will in all likelihood be a Yankee through the next nine World Series and two Summer Olympics, and when today's 10-year-old is packing for college. He may also by the summer of 2017 be baseball's career home run leader, but a 42-year-old designated hitter and financial albatross for a high-roller franchise that fancifully took on long-term debt while assuming the market for professional sports would never plateau, much less plunge.
 No one can say if the business of baseball is flourishing inside a proverbial bubble, or outside the proposed bailout. But there are some signs of a sports reckoning, especially for those accustomed to living in a manner that some would call grotesquely and dangerously large. 
 ''This is a critical off-season for a team like the Yankees, in particular,'' Marc Ganis, a well-connected sports industry consultant, said in a telephone interview. ''They are opening a new stadium but at a time their fan base is going to have to be more prudent in how they spend. Meanwhile, the Yankees are in a position where they have to keep spending to improve their team because that's the deal they've made with their fans, but during a serious downturn that is having its greatest impact on the auto industry, which is by far the largest sponsor of pro sports.''
 To underscore that last point, General Motors recently announced that it would not purchase advertising time during the Super Bowl in February, with a spokeswoman explaining that the company is ''in the midst of cost cutting'' and ''scrutinizing all of our programs and all of our media spending.''
 Only a team or league executive asleep at the cash register would at this moment hold to the longtime belief that sports as live, unscripted entertainment must remain a growth product, immune to global instability. According to Ganis, no less an industry titan than N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell two months ago circulated a memo warning of revenue declines and suggesting teams tighten their belts.
 At the N.H.L. Board of Governors meeting late last month in Toronto, the group was briefed on the crisis. The commissioner, Gary Bettman, told The Canadian Press, ''Obviously nobody can predict how this is going to unfold and when there might be a recovery.'' 
 Pucks, balls, cars -- sports of all shapes and sounds are concerned, or should be. The Associated Press recently reported, ''The global financial crises likely will hit Formula One unless administrators start controlling costs, team owners and officials said.'' Time Magazine's Web site weighed in on how English Premier League soccer teams are facing the teetering of main sponsors like the American International Group (Manchester United) and Northern Rock (Newcastle). 
 ''For the teams counting on certain corporations to buy the most expensive luxury suites, well, some of those corporations are no longer there,'' Ganis said. 
 For his part, Ganis is of the opinion that New York's huge population and ultracompetitive business culture shrinks the likelihood of a major backlash as its teams embark on a price-gouging era under challenging circumstances. He said he believed that whatever cutbacks occurred in the short term, professional sports were well-positioned so the impact would not be lasting, or severe.
 ''That's assuming they avoid spending like drunken sailors,'' he said. ''But baseball above all does have a history of spending in irrational ways.''
 Led by those longtime practitioners of scorched-earth financial policies, the Bronx-based franchise informally known as the Bombers.
 The most common contemporary take on the Yankees is that their deep pockets do not guarantee championship success, just the ability to withstand expensive mistakes (Carl Pavano, Kei Igawa, Roger Clemens in 2007) that would level lesser-endowed clubs. But given higher stakes and increased risk, for how long? 
 With a personnel infrastructure almost as old as the stadium they are vacating, with an overhyped or underachieving farm system, how do the Yankees meet the terms of their aforementioned deal with their fans without sending the newly re-signed general manager, Brian Cashman, on a pressurized spending spree that would compromise the financial restraint he preached in passing on Johan Santana last winter?
 ''A $40 million mistake four years ago could be a $120 million mistake today, like Barry Zito and the Giants,'' Ganis said. ''And by the way, if you're the Yankees and you're paying the luxury tax, it's $175 million.''
 Yankee tax dollars subsidize smaller markets. The more the Yankees spend without optimum return, the greater the odds of a Tampa Bay rising up against them. The richer and longer a contract the Yankees hand out, the more they are stuck with the status quo, for better or worse.
 Take A-Rod. He's a force of nature now, but if his skills erode sooner than later, the Yankees may want to say, ''Take him, please.'' At the price they paid, good luck with that, and with selling those overpriced seats long term in their expensive new house if safer, smarter investments are not soon made.

HEADLINE: Revolutionary Hero, Relentless Heroine

BYLINE: By MANOHLA DARGIS

 BODY:
Hollywood meets Havana as the 46th New York Film Festival glides and sometimes stumbles into its second week. In ''Che,''Benicio Del Toro, wearing a jaunty beret and wispy tufts of beard, wages war against Yankee-supported states in Steven Soderbergh's 257-minute (with a 30-minute bladder break) historical epic. Meanwhile in ''Changeling,'' Clint Eastwood's 141-minute period drama, Angelina Jolie, wearing a jaunty cloche and bloody slash of lipstick, does battle against the patriarchs of 1920s Los Angeles. 
 ''Che'' and ''Changeling'' were first shown in May at the Cannes Film Festival, where they were swaddled in hype and hysteria and anointed with tears of critical joy and fury. Other similarities: both were directed by men who have always maintained a distance from the studios for which they profitably work. Both also hinge on bankable Hollywood stars -- Mr. Del Toro as Che, Ms. Jolie as Christine Collins -- and feature recognizable faces in supporting roles. Lou Diamond Phillips plays a sissy Communist leader in ''Che,'' in which a distracting Matt Damon pops up as a man of peace. I didn't notice any pinkos in ''Changeling,'' but John Malkovich goes all righteous and solemn as a man of the cloth. 
 Divided into two sections -- once called ''The Argentine'' and ''Guerrilla'' -- the now monosyllabically titled ''Che'' tracks the guerrilla leader over mountains and through his tactical successes in Cuba before moving on to his catastrophic bid to bring revolutionary socialism to Bolivia. The movie has been described as dialectical, but two parts do not a dialectic make: something meaningful has to happen between those parts. Throughout the movie Mr. Soderbergh mixes the wild beauty of his landscapes with images of Che heroically engaged in battle, thoughtfully scribbling and reading, and tending to ailing peasants and soldiers. Che wins, Che loses, but Che remains the same in what plays like a procedural about a charismatic leader, impossible missions and the pleasures of work and camaraderie -- ''Ocean's Eleven'' with better cigars.
 Like that glossy, glistening bauble of a film, ''Che'' seems to me very much a self-reflexive endeavor, a movie not just about two revolutionary campaigns, but also about the struggles -- logistical, emotional, psychological -- of moviemaking itself. (To push this analogy further, Mr. Soderbergh's first feature, ''sex, lies, and videotape,'' is his Cuba -- an act of youthful will and the spark that ignited a movement -- while his second feature, a stubborn folly called ''Kafka,'' could have been his Bolivia.) Mr. Soderbergh cagily evades Che's ugly side, notably his increasing commitment to violence and seemingly endless war, but the movie is without question political -- even if it emphasizes romantic adventure over realpolitik -- because, like all films, it is predicated on getting, spending and making money. It opens in December. 
 I admire Mr. Soderbergh's filmmaking more than his movie, but ''Che'' is the kind of bold choice that should be included in a festival that needs to shake things up if it is to remain relevant. Alas, the selection of Mr. Eastwood's ''Changeling'' is nothing if not predictable and was, I'm guessing, either selected out of loyalty to a revered auteur or because it will provide a red-carpet thrill for the donors of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which presents the festival. This fall movie season certainly looks thin, which suggests that programming pickings were slim. But ''Changeling,'' embalmed by Ms. Jolie's waxworks performance and a sepulchral production design, adds no luster to Mr. Eastwood's reputation or the festival's. It will doubtless earn Ms. Jolie another shot at an Oscar. 
 Programmer loyalty seems the only explanation for the inclusion of ''Night and Day,'' a meandering, bloated bore from the South Korean director Hong Sang-soo. Beginning in the mid-1990s, Mr. Hong began a terrific run with formally audacious, emotionally nuanced films like ''The Power of Kangwon Province,'' ''Virgin Stripped Bare by Her Bachelors'' and ''Woman Is the Future of Man.'' Though he stumbled a few years ago with ''Tale of Cinema,'' he returned to sturdy form with ''Woman on the Beach,'' which was shown in the 2006 New York festival. Set in Paris, ''Night and Day'' centers on a Korean roue and his (inexplicably) many women, and seems vaguely interested in the question of cultural difference, but is mostly about Mr. Hong playing tourist while fiddling with the zoom. 
 The exacting formalism and beauty of ''The Headless Woman,'' the latest from the Argentine filmmaker Lucrecia Martel -- last seen at the festival with ''The Holy Girl'' -- is undeniable. The film centers on Veronica (a mesmerizing, zomboid Maria Onetto), who, while reaching for her cellphone one day, runs over what she comes to think may have been a child. She doesn't report the accident, and it soon emerges that her greater crime is being bourgeois. The film's opener -- a series of glidingly crosscut images of children running and Veronica fussing with her girlfriends, capped by the haunting image of palm prints fading on a car window -- is a tour de force of economical storytelling that makes the next 80 or so minutes moot. 
 ''Afterschool'' is American art-house horror from Antonio Campos (a baby Michael Haneke) about privileged young things blankly staring into pulsing screens on their way to perdition. ''Four Nights With Anna,'' about a stalker and the nurse he loves, is the latest from the Polish director Jerzy Skolimowski, whose earlier films include ''Deep End.'' Just as dark in mood is Matteo Garrone's ''Gomorrah,'' a ferociously unsentimental and fictionalized look at the Neapolitan Mafia, which opens early next year. Also playing is ''The Windmill Movie,'' a video portrait that Alexander Olch patched together from autobiographical material shot by his (and my) former teacher, the filmmaker Richard P. Rogers, who died in 2001. Mr. Rogers's lovely 1970 short ''Quarry,'' which is showing with the feature, is the real find here. 
 Also screening this week are Max Ophuls's 1955 drama ''Lola Montes,'' about a 19th-century courtesan who becomes a circus attraction -- this is the third time the film has played in the festival -- and ''Ashes of Time Redux,'' Wong Kar-wai's rethink (or re-something) of his 1994 martial-arts marvel, ''Ashes of Time.'' Made during a long, difficult shoot -- so protracted that Mr. Wong shot ''Chungking Express'' during a hiatus -- the original ''Ashes of Time'' was a transitional work for the filmmaker, who came close to shaking off narrative entirely in favor of pure abstraction. An insanely beautiful swirl of Fauvist colors and glorious faces belonging to Leslie Cheung, Maggie Cheung and Brigitte Lin, among others, the redone film seems even more abstract and even more of a triumph. It opens in theaters next Friday.
 The 46th New York Film Festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, continues through Oct. 12. Information and tickets: (212) 721-6500; filmlinc.com.

HEADLINE: As Economy Weakens, Federal Reserve Officials Consider Lowering Rates

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Even if Congress approves President Bush's $700 billion rescue plan for Wall Street, top officials at the Federal Reserve believe the economy will slow down more than they had expected as recently as July.
 As a result, Fed officials are considering yet another reduction in the central bank's benchmark interest rate. The matter is by no means settled, in part because some officials are skeptical that a reduction in the overnight federal funds rate would make much difference. 
 The biggest obstacle to economic activity right now is not the shortage of cash but the unwillingness of financial institutions to lend it out, even to each other. Overnight lending rates among banks remain far higher than the federal funds rate. The ''TED spread,'' the difference between overnight rates among banks and the yield on Treasury bills, hit a new record of 3.61 percentage points. 
 But Fed officials have been deluged with data suggesting that the underlying economy has slowed more than they had been expecting, and many private analysts contend the economy has already entered a recession. At the same time, inflation pressures have declined slightly, mainly because oil prices have declined from their record highs this year.
 The Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has been trying to deal with the liquidity problems -- the difficulty of businesses to line up short-term financing for normal activities -- separately from the more basic problem of a possible recession. 
 For practical purposes, fears about potential insolvencies are so high that many corporate borrowers and institutional investors can get only overnight loans to finance their operations. Indeed, credit markets are more paralyzed now than they were in August 2007, when the markets seized up in fear over mortgage-backed securities.
 The Fed, along with central banks from around the world, has pumped hundreds of billions of dollars into the financial system in recent days to get banks lending again. So far, those efforts have had little discernible effect. But Fed and Treasury officials are hoping that the money markets will start to thaw more if Congress allows the government to buy as much as $700 billion in troubled mortgages and mortgage-backed securities.
 The decision to reduce interest rates will depend on whether policy makers decide that the economy is slowing more than they had already been expecting. Fed officials had already been predicting a slowdown in the second half of 2008.
 But Mr. Bernanke warned the Joint Economic Committee of Congress last week that the economy would grow at a pace ''appreciably below'' normal for the second half of the year and that the credit squeeze had damaged economic growth for the months ahead.
 ''I see the financial markets as already quite fragile,'' he told lawmakers. ''The credit markets aren't working. Corporations aren't able to finance themselves through commercial paper. Even if the situation stayed as it did today, that would be a significant drag on the economy.''
 Mr. Bernanke also warned that the two main reasons for the nation's fairly healthy growth in the second quarter -- tax rebates and rising exports -- would provide little help for the rest of the year. The tax rebates were finished by June, and global economic growth had slowed and reduced demand for American exports.
 That economic outlook was much darker than it was at the Fed's last policy meeting on Sept. 16, when policy makers held rates steady at 2 percent and declared that the ''downside'' risks to growth and the ''upside'' risks of higher inflation were both ''significant concerns.''
 Mr. Bernanke thus far has not predicted that the economy would actually slide into a recession, but Fed officials have received a stream of grim economic reports.
 On Thursday, a closely-watched survey of manufacturing activity plunged to a level that economists associated with a recession. The Institute for Supply Management reported that its monthly index of activity fell to 43.5 in September from 49.9 the month before. In general, a reading below 50 indicates that manufacturers are contracting rather than expanding.
 The United States has lost jobs every month since December, for a total of 770,000 through the end of August. On Thursday, the Labor Department reported 497,000 new claims for unemployment benefits in the previous week. Many economists estimate that if new claims run higher than 400,000 a week, as they have been for months now, the economy is losing more jobs than it is creating.
 On Friday, economists expect the Labor Department to report another net decline in the labor market of about 100,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: Brainy Brand Names Where They're Least Expected

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
A FINANCIAL crisis, two wars, a presidential election. ... When there is so much for readers to think about, how do magazines aimed at thoughtful readers attract their attention?
 One such magazine, The Economist, is spoofing the game Twister, distributing pizza boxes that improbably bear its name and sponsoring a performance of political satire by the Second City theatrical troupe.
 Another such magazine, The Atlantic, plans to advertise on the muffin displays in bodegas, restaurant menu boards and the shampoo shelves of drugstores. 
 The Atlantic is also producing video clips that show what happens when passers-by on city streets are invited to answer questions like ''Is Google making us stupid?'' and ''Why do presidents lie?'' -- questions that, to make them stand out, have also been reproduced as neon signs.
 In seeking readers and advertisers, publications like The Atlantic and The Economist, known as thought-leader magazines, have long tried to make up in cleverness what they lack in wallet power. Their ranks also include magazines like Harper's, Mother Jones, The Nation, The New Republic and The New Yorker.
 The campaign for The Atlantic, with a budget estimated at $1.5 million, even evokes its identity as a thought-leader title; it carries the theme ''Think. Again.'' The campaign, which will also include a section of the magazine's Web site (theatlantic.com/thinkagain) is to begin on Monday. 
 The campaign for The Economist is arriving this week in Philadelphia after stopping in eight other markets, including Boston and Washington. The campaign, with a budget estimated at $5 million, carries the theme ''Get a world view.''
 Both campaigns are indicative of the increasingly unusual efforts by the traditional media to catch the wandering eyes of younger readers as well as younger employees of media agencies who help decide where marketers buy ads.
 The theory is that they ''should be jolted,'' said Justin Smith, president for consumer media at the Atlantic Media Company in Washington.
 ''We felt there was a great opportunity, right now, to further inspire our readers and advertisers,'' he added.
 His counterpart at The Economist, Paul Rossi, who is based in New York, echoed Mr. Smith's decision to seize the moment, fraught as it might be with uncertainty.
 ''I think it's the best possible time'' for a campaign, said Mr. Rossi, executive vice president and managing director for the Americas at The Economist.
 ''What we have to say has never been more relevant,'' he added. ''We write about the world, about connections between business and politics.'' The media company Pearson owns a 50 percent stake in The Economist through The Financial Times.
 The questions appearing in the campaign for The Atlantic are from articles published in the magazine. Some have stimulated newsstand sales, Mr. Smith said, citing the issue with the article about Google, which sold about 82,000 copies versus the recent average of 42,000.
 The circulation that The Atlantic guarantees to advertisers, known as a rate base, is 400,000 this year and is to be increased to 450,000 in 2009. That includes newsstand sales and subscriptions.
 The ads for The Atlantic in unexpected locales like bodegas are meant to reach media buyers where they eat, buy takeout food and shop. Those are ''places where people's brains are most at rest,'' said Michael Fanuele, managing director for strategy at the magazine's creative agency, Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas.
 The video clips, aimed at readers as well as advertisers, will be available on the Think Again section of The Atlantic Web site, and plans call for additional content to be added monthly.
 Previews of the clips offer a wide variety of responses from the passers-by. On the question ''Why do presidents lie?,'' the replies ranged from ''Why do we let them?'' to ''There'd be more problems if we told the truth.''
 The neon signs, which also appear in print ads and posters, will decorate events sponsored by The Atlantic and eventually end up at the magazine's offices. ''We hope to keep one or two for ourselves,'' said Jose Cabaco, chief creative officer for North America at Euro RSCG.
 Other agencies working on the campaign for The Atlantic are Cleverworks, for media buying, and the Rosen Group, for public relations.
 There are several agencies working on the campaign for The Economist: BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, for the creative content; PHD, also part of Omnicom, for media buying; Kinetic, a unit of the WPP Group, for outdoor ads; and Tentpole N.Y. for public relations and events like the Second City performance, part of a three-day program called Off the Page.
 ''It's always a good time to read The Economist,'' said Andrew Robertson, chief executive at BBDO, ''but if there ever was a good time to be reading The Economist, it's now.''
 Originally, the ads run by The Economist in this country were adapted from a popular campaign for the magazine created in London by the Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO unit of BBDO. Headlines from that campaign -- called the ''white-on-red campaign'' for its color scheme, borrowed from the logo of The Economist -- include ''Great minds like a think'' and Mr. Robertson's favorite, ''Would you like to sit next to you at dinner?''
 The idea behind the British campaign ''is that if you read it, you'd be better informed, and therefore more successful,'' he said, ''which evolved into, you'd be better informed, and therefore more interesting.''
 The new ads with the Twister parody and the like are from the BBDO office in New York so they will more directly address American sensibilities, Mr. Robertson said, and provide ''a more specific explanation of what you'll get from reading The Economist.''
 ''If you look at some of the titles that compete with The Economist, their perspective is from the U.S. looking at the world,'' he added, ''whereas with The Economist the focus is the world view.''
 The rate base for The Economist in North America is 714,000. Its worldwide circulation -- rate bases are not guaranteed outside North America -- is almost 1.34 million.

HEADLINE: A Political Debate With Its Fair Share of Inaccuracies

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER, PETER BAKER, LARRY ROHTER and MICHAEL LUO; Kitty Bennett contributed reporting.

 BODY:
The vice-presidential debate on Thursday contained a fair share of distortions and misstatements. Here are some of them:
 Iraq and Afghanistan
 Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, and Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, the Republican, sharply disagreed on whether a rapid reinforcement of troops and the application of counterinsurgency strategy as developed in Iraq would work in neighboring Afghanistan.
 Mr. Biden said the American commanding general in Afghanistan had said Thursday (he actually spoke on Wednesday) that a ''surge'' in troops would not work there because of differences in military and civic challenges between Iraq and Afghanistan.
 Ms. Palin said the general had called for more troops -- in essence, a ''surge'' -- and said the counterinsurgency strategy that had reduced the violence in Iraq could also work in Afghanistan. 
 In citing the general's remarks, Mr. Biden did not name him. Ms. Palin referred to him as ''McClellan.'' The commander is Gen. David D. McKiernan of the Army. 
 Both Mr. Biden and Ms. Palin were partly right. General McKiernan declined to use the term ''surge,'' but also called for a quick infusion of troops to pursue counterinsurgency operations similar to those in Iraq but on a different scale and over a different politico-military landscape.
 General McKiernan said in a Pentagon briefing on Wednesday that he needed more troops quickly to accomplish his mission of defeating insurgents, drug lords and the Taliban.
 ''The word I don't use for Afghanistan is 'surge,' '' General McKiernan told reporters in Washington, where he was attending high-level meetings to review United States policy in Afghanistan. ''There needs to be a sustained commitment of a variety of military and nonmilitary resources, I believe. That's my advice to winning in Afghanistan. It won't be a short-term solution.''
 Mr. Biden and his Democratic running mate, Senator Barack Obama have called Afghanistan ''the central front in the war on terror'' and are calling for deployment of additional American combat brigades there. They do not call such an increase a ''surge,'' however, as that term has been applied in Iraq.
 Ms. Palin said the general ''did not say definitively that the surge principles would not work in Afghanistan.'' She went on to acknowledge that '' conditions are certainly different.'' 
 The general did say some aspects of the Iraq counterinsurgency strategy, like the effort to engage tribal leaders in political dialogue, could yield fruit in Afghanistan, which has long been dominated by regional and tribal warlords. He said there were significant differences between the two countries and the two conflicts, however.
 JOHN M. BRODER 
 Troop Withdrawals
 Mr. Biden described Mr. Obama's plan for withdrawing troops from Iraq as ''ironically, the same plan that Maliki, the prime minister of Iraq, and George Bush are now negotiating.'' He added, ''The only odd man here, the one left out, is John McCain.''
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Obama are closer today in their vision for Iraq than they used to be, but there are still important differences. Mr. Obama has promised to withdraw combat forces from Iraq within 16 months of taking office, which would mean mid-2010. Mr. Bush, after years of resisting timetables, has signaled willingness to set a goal for withdrawing by the end of 2011.
 Mr. Bush and Nouri al-Maliki, the Iraqi prime minister, are negotiating a strategic framework for American-Iraqi relations and a status of forces agreement that would govern the presence of American troops in Iraq after a United Nations mandate expires at the end of this year. Mr. Bush still maintains that any withdrawals would be ''aspirational'' and contingent on conditions on the ground. PETER BAKER 
 Troops Deployed
 Criticizing the Democratic candidates for their opposition to ''the surge'' in Iraq that has been one of the bedrocks of Mr. McCain's national security policy, Ms. Palin asserted that ''we're down to pre-surge numbers'' of troops in Iraq. 
 In reality, there are about 146,000 troops still serving in Iraq. That is roughly 11,000 more than the number deployed there before the start of the troop build-up early last year that came to be known as ''the surge.'' 
 It is true that President Bush last month announced he intended to withdraw some 8,000 combat and support troops over the next few months. But even that withdrawal, if it were to occur at the pace and in the amount the president wants, would still leave at least 138,000 troops in Iraq.
 LARRY ROHTER 
 Rebuilding Afghanistan
 Mr. Biden said, ''We spend more money in three weeks on combat in Iraq than we spent on the entirety of the last seven years that we have been in Afghanistan building that country.'' This appears to be exaggerated, although it is not exactly clear what Mr. Biden was including under ''building that country.'' 
 The Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation, a nonpartisan group, estimates American spending in Iraq at $2.4 billion a week, based on a report this year by the Congressional Research Service. That would put a three-week total at $7.2 billion.
 In June the State Department said security and reconstruction assistance to Afghanistan from fiscal year 2001 to 2008 amounted to $26 billion, including $7.7 billion for economic and social development, $17.2 billion for security and $1.3 billion on ''governance, rule of law and human rights.'' 
 MICHAEL LUO 
 Health Care 
 Ms. Palin castigated Mr. Obama's health care plan as one that would mandate a ''universal government-run'' system in which health care is ''taken over'' by the federal government.
 This is inaccurate on several levels. Mr. Obama's proposal, which he hopes will result in ''universal'' coverage in which everyone has health insurance, includes an option for people to choose a new public plan with benefits similar to what members of Congress and other federal employees currently have. 
 It also includes an expansion of Medicaid and the State Children's Health Insurance Program, but it is not at all exclusively government-run. It preserves the existing employer-based health insurance system, offering subsidies or tax credits to help those who cannot afford premiums. Mr. Obama's plan also mandates only that children, not adults, have coverage.
 MICHAEL LUO 
 Tax Increases
 In addressing the issues of taxes, Ms. Palin revived an accusation that he and Mr. Biden voted ''for the largest tax increases in U.S. history'' and also charged that he would raise taxes ''for those families making only $42,000 a year.'' 
 Mr. Obama voted twice this year in favor of a budget resolution that would have allowed the tax cuts that President Bush pushed through Congress in 2001 and 2003 to expire at the end of 2010, as the original law mandated. But that, by the definition of the Congressional Budget Office and other tax experts, does not constitute a tax increase.
 The resolution, if not accompanied by other tax changes, envisages an increase in taxes for an individual earning $42,000 a year who has no dependents and owns no real estate. It would not apply to a family. Estimates are that a family of four making $90,000 would not see a tax increase.
 In addition, the McCain campaign months ago abandoned its argument that Mr. Obama now favors a historic tax increase. It did so after tax analysts and other economists debunked the assertion, saying that nothing contemplated by either party comes anywhere near the tax increases put into effect to fight World War II. Ms. Palin, however, revived the accusation. LARRY ROHTER

HEADLINE: Excerpt From the Vice-Presidential Debate

 BODY:
An excerpt from the vice-presidential debate on Thursday night in St. Louis, between Gov. Sarah Palin and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., as recorded by CQ Transcriptions. The moderator was Gwen Ifill of PBS. A full transcript and video: nytimes.com/politics.
 MR. BIDEN I'm not going to change. I have 35 years in public office. People can judge who I am. I haven't changed in that time. 
 And, by the way, a record of change -- I will place my record and Barack's record against John McCain's or anyone else in terms of fundamental accomplishments. 
 Wrote the crime bill, put 100,000 cops on the street, wrote the Violence Against Women Act, which John McCain voted against, both of them, was the catalyst to change the circumstance in Bosnia, led by President Clinton, obviously.
 Look, I understand what it's like to be a single parent. When my wife and daughter died and my two sons were gravely injured, I understand what it's like as a parent to wonder what it's like if your kid's going to make it.
 I understand what it's like to sit around the kitchen table with a father who says, ''I've got to leave, champ, because there's no jobs here. I got to head down to Wilmington. And when we get enough money, honey, we'll bring you down.''
 I understand what it's like. I'm much better off than almost all Americans now. I get a good salary with the United States Senate. I live in a beautiful house that's my total investment that I have. So I am much better off now.
 But the notion that somehow, because I'm a man, I don't know what it's like to raise two kids alone, I don't know what it's like to have a child you're not sure is going to make it -- I understand.
 I understand, as well as, with all due respect, the governor or anybody else, what it's like for those people sitting around that kitchen table. And guess what? They're looking for help. They're looking for help. They're not looking for more of the same.
 MS. IFILL Governor?
 MS. PALIN People aren't looking for more of the same. They are looking for change. And John McCain has been the consummate maverick in the Senate over all these years.
 He's taken shots left and right from the other party and from within his own party, because he's had to take on his own party when the time was right, when he recognized it was time to put partisanship aside and just do what was right for the American people. That's what I've done as governor, also, take on my own party, when I had to, and work with both sides of the aisle, in my cabinet, appointing those who would serve regardless of party, Democrats, independents, Republicans, whatever it took to get the job done.
 Also, John McCain's maverick position that he's in, that's really prompt up to and indicated by the supporters that he has. Look at Lieberman, and Giuliani, and Romney, and Lingle, and all of us who come from such a diverse background of policy and of partisanship, all coming together at this time, recognizing he is the man that we need to lead in these next four years, because these are tumultuous times.
 We have got to win the wars. We have got to get our economy back on track. We have got to not allow the greed and corruption on Wall Street anymore. And we have not got to allow the partisanship that has really been entrenched in Washington, D.C., no matter who's been in charge. 
 When the Republicans were in charge, I didn't see a lot of progress there, either. When the Democrats, either, though, this last go-around for the last two years.
 Change is coming. And John McCain is the leader of that reform.

HEADLINE: Signaling Confidence in Support, House to Vote on Rescue Proposal

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR; David Stout contributed reporting.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
House Democrats said late Thursday night that they would bring the $700 billion economic bailout package to the floor for a vote on Friday, signaling confidence that they had enough support to pass the bill.
 The move came after Republican leaders struggled on Thursday to persuade some of their members to reverse course and support the package and after top Democrats said earlier that that they would not bring the bill to the floor unless they were certain of victory. 
 ''I'm hopeful that there will be bipartisan, majority support for this bill that is critical to stabilizing our nation's economy for all working Americans,'' said the majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, who said the House would consider the bill Friday morning.
 Earlier Thursday, the White House and Congressional leaders maneuvered to drum up support and several lawmakers in each party said they were prepared to switch their votes. 
 But others agonized amid a continuing deluge of calls from angry constituents. 
 The Senate approved the bailout plan on Wednesday night with a solid bipartisan majority, 74 to 25, after adding a thick portfolio of popular tax provisions. 
 The Senate action came after House members defied the leadership of both parties and rejected the plan on Monday. The House vote fell 12 votes short, with Republicans opposed by a two to one margin. It was opposed by 95 Democrats and 133 Republicans. 
 The Senate proposal included more than $150 billion in tax breaks, including incentives for solar, wind and other renewable energy sources, but it included offsets to pay for only $43 billion, infuriating fiscally conservative Democrats in the House. 
 ''We may lose people,'' Mr. Hoyer said earlier in the day. ''Because frankly, the things that were added on and the way they were added on essentially appeal to Republicans.''
 In response to Mr. Hoyer's announcement, Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, the No. 2 House Republican and a chief negotiator of the bailout plan, said party leaders were optimistic but still pushing for support.
 ''While I believe we have increased support on both sides of the aisle for this economic rescue package, we are leaving nothing to chance,'' Mr. Blunt said in a statement. ''The stakes are simply too high. Leading up to the vote, we will continue to work with our members to get this critical piece across the finish line.''
 But apparently it was not overwhelmingly appealing because only a few Republicans stated publicly that they were prepared to switch their votes to yes. 
 One of them, Zach Wamp, Republican of Tennessee, said the economy was just in too precarious a state. 
 ''The time has come to act,'' Mr. Wamp said in an interview on Fox Television. ''If we do not go on the wall, it will be an ugly day in America.''
 Representative Jim Ramstad, Republican of Minnesota, said he also intended to switch and vote in favor because the Senate had added a provision requiring equivalence, or parity, in insurance coverage of mental and physical ailments. 
 ''The revised bill is a recovery bill for the economy and a recovery bill for millions of Americans suffering the ravages of mental illness and addiction,'' said Mr. Ramstad, who has been working for ''mental health parity'' for more than a decade. 
 There was also movement among some Democrats. Emanuel Cleaver II, Democrat of Missouri, announced that he would switch to yes from no. And John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, also planned to switch, Democratic aides said. 
 A small group of Republicans said they were still hoping to amend the bill, and to reduce the amount of money the Treasury could spend on troubled assets of ailing financial firms to $250 billion, from $700 billion. Democrats said they had no plans to allow amendments, which would require the Senate to vote again, further delaying the plan. 
 After last Monday's rejection of the bailout plan, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 778 points, vote-counters in both parties said they were leaving nothing to chance. 
 They were hunting for votes in precincts of Texas and Louisiana hurt by Hurricane Ike, and in storm-ravaged communities in the Midwest, pointing to $7.6 billion in disaster aid in the bill. 
 They were scouring districts in northern New Jersey and other affluent suburbs with promises of relief from the alternative minimum tax. And they were looking to rural areas in the West, with aid for schools and for loggers and other struggling industries. 
 All of these so-called sweeteners were part of a package of tax provisions, many of them related to the production and use of energy from renewable sources, that the Senate added to the bailout plan before easily approving the expanded package.
 Some House Democrats reacted furiously. They support many of the tax provisions and previously approved them, but had insisted they be offset by cuts in spending elsewhere. The Senate version added $107 billion in deficit spending. 
 Mr. Hoyer said that some Democrats also wanted to amend the bill to add an extension of unemployment benefits, but that change would also have required additional Senate action. ''I am not very sympathetic, necessarily, with making the Senate wait,'' he said. ''But I am sympathetic to making the economy wait. That is the problem.''
 To stave off another surprise defeat, House leaders were looking to build a comfortable cushion of votes before heading to the floor, and they enlisted the help of both presidential nominees, Senators John McCain of Arizona and Barack Obama of Illinois. 
 President Bush, at a meeting with business leaders, urged Americans to call their representatives in Congress and demand that they vote for the bailout plan, which would authorize the Treasury to buy up to $700 billion in troubled debt from financial firms. 
 ''The bill that came over from the Senate includes a series of pork-barrel projects that are simply unacceptable not only to me but to the American people,'' said Representative Spencer Bachus, Republican of Alabama. 
 Mr. Bachus voted for the bailout on Monday but did not say how he would vote on Friday, echoing many other lawmakers. 
 The phones were ringing nonstop in the office of Representative Steven R. Rothman, Democrat of New Jersey. Mr. Rothman voted against the bailout Monday, but many of his constituents would benefit from a provision to protect millions of middle-class families from paying the alternative minimum tax.
 A spokesman said Mr. Rothman had not decided whether to switch his vote. 
 Representative Steven C. LaTourette, Republican of Ohio, said he believed that 15 House members would shift from no to yes if the pork-barrel tax items were eliminated and if the bill put tighter restrictions on the secretary of the Treasury. 
 But other Republicans who voted no on Monday said they would hold firm. ''I am a firmer 'no,' '' said Representative Joe Barton, Republican of Texas, who party leaders had thought might flip. ''I don't want to see the debt ceiling increased on $1 trillion with no way to pay for it.''

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Editorial Desk; EDITORIAL; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 621 words

HEADLINE: The Vice-Presidential Debate

 BODY:
We cannot recall when there were lower expectations for a candidate than the ones that preceded Sarah Palin's appearance in Thursday night's vice-presidential debate with Joseph Biden. After a series of stumbling interviews that raised serious doubts even among conservatives about her fitness to serve as vice president, Ms. Palin had to do little more than say one or two sensible things and avoid an election-defining gaffe.
 By that standard, but only by that standard, the governor of Alaska did well. But Ms. Palin never really got beyond her talking points in 90 minutes, mostly repeating cliches and tired attack lines and energetically refusing to answer far too many questions. 
 Senator Biden did well, avoiding one of his own infamous gaffes, while showing a clear grasp of the big picture and the details. He left Ms. Palin way behind on most issues, especially foreign policy and national security, where she just seemed lost. It was in those moments that her lack of experience -- two terms as mayor of a tiny Anchorage suburb and less than two years as governor -- was most painfully evident. 
 Asked about Israel, Ms. Palin reeled off her support for ''a two-state solution, building our embassy also in Jerusalem, those things that we look forward to being able to accomplish with this peace-seeking nation.'' Asked about the possible use of nuclear weapons, she declared ''nuclear weaponry, of course, would be the be-all, end-all of just too many people and too many parts of our planet.'' On Iraq, all she had to offer was the false accusation that Barack Obama wants to surrender. 
 Mr. Biden directly challenged Ms. Palin's debate prep on Afghanistan -- pointing out that the commander there had disagreed with Mr. McCain's call for an Iraq-style ''surge'' in Afghanistan. Ms. Palin tried to contradict him, but the most memorable part of her answer was that she got the general's name wrong. 
 One can argue (and her supporters will) that Ms. Palin is a newcomer and can't be expected to know all of the wonkish details, that what matters is the image she projects. Except, anyone who is running for vice president in these very dangerous times needs to have detailed knowledge. 
 When it came to domestic issues, Ms. Palin mainly relied on enthusiasm and humor, talking about hockey moms, soccer moms and Joe Sixpack almost as often as she used the word ''maverick'' to describe Mr. McCain or herself.
 But she offered virtually no detail -- beyond the Republican mantra of tax cuts -- for how she and Mr. McCain would address the financial crisis or help Americans avoid foreclosure or what programs they would cut because of the country's disastrous fiscal problems.
 Ms. Palin's primary tactic was simply to repeat the same thing over and over: John McCain is a maverick. So is she. To stay on that course, she had to indulge in some wildly circular logic: America does not want another Washington insider. They want Mr. McCain (who has been in Congress for nearly 26 years). Ms. Palin condemned Wall Street greed and said she and Mr. McCain would ''demand'' strict oversight. In virtually the next breath, she said government should ''get out of the way'' of American business.
 There were occasional, disturbing flashes of the old, pre-campaign Sarah Palin. Asked about the causes of global warming, Ms. Palin suggested that man had some role -- but she wasn't saying how much.
 In the end, the debate did not change the essential truth of Ms. Palin's candidacy: Mr. McCain made a wildly irresponsible choice that shattered the image he created for himself as the honest, seasoned, experienced man of principle and judgment. It was either an act of incredible cynicism or appallingly bad judgment.

SECTION: EDUCATION

LENGTH: 2218 words

HEADLINE: Power and Influence, While Second in Line

BYLINE: ANNISSA HAMBOUZ and KRISTIN MCGINN MAHONEY


HIGHLIGHT: In this lesson, students investigate the role and duties of the vice president of the United States; they then write persuasive essays in favor of one of this year's running mates using supporting evidence from The New York Times. ( for a companion lesson for Grades 3-5.) 

 BODY:
Overview of Lesson Plan: In this lesson, students investigate the role and duties of the vice president of the United States; then they write persuasive essays in favor of one of this year's running mates using supporting evidence from The New York Times. ( for a companion lesson for Grades 3-5.)
Author(s):
Annissa Hambouz, The New York Times Learning Network
Kristin McGinn Mahoney , The New York Times Learning Network
Suggested Time Allowance: 3-4 class periods
Objectives:
Students will:
1. Investigate the official role and duties of the vice president and discuss some of the responsibilities of vice presidents from past administrations.
2. Read and discuss the article "Palin and Biden Are Cordial but Pointed."
3. Delve further into the vice president's role in the Constitution and in history; evaluate the backgrounds and qualifications of, as well as the televised debate between, the Democratic and Republican vice presidential candidates.
4. Write a persuasive essay in support of one of this year's vice presidential candidates.
Activities / Procedures:
 for a companion lesson for Grades 3-5.
1. WARM-UP/DO NOW
Engage students in a brief discussion about the vice presidential debate. How many students watched the debate? How many have heard, read or seen news coverage about it? What are their impressions? Then ask: In general, how important do you think the role of vice president of the United States is? Why?
Next, have students take a brief True/False quiz on the roles of the vice president of the United States using the handout found at . (Answers are, in order: True, False, False, True, True, False, False.)
Allow students several minutes to work, and then share and discuss responses as a class. If students are unfamiliar with the vice president's constitutional duty to preside over the Senate, explain that they will be investigating this role and other issues related to the vice presidency in this lesson. You may also wish to briefly discuss the vice president's roles as "acting president" when the president is unable to perform his or her normal duties and as first in line of succession to the presidency.
2. As a class, read and discuss the article " Palin and Biden Are Cordial but Pointed" (), focusing on the following questions:
a. On what issues did the vice presidential candidates spar in this debate?
b. How, according to this article, did the candidates come across? What words does the article use to describe the overall tone of the debate?
c. What do you think were the most memorable moments of the evening? Why?
d. Why was this highly anticipated debate "packed with political importance" as well as a "cultural event," according to the article? Do you think it will significantly change either team's chances in the November election?
e. Which, if either, of the candidates do you feel "won" this debate? Why?
3. ACTIVITY
After you have read and discussed the article as a class, have students revisit the role and duties of the vice president, which were introduced in the initial activity.
Focus on either the constitutional role of the vice president and/or on the history of how various vice presidents have interpreted and performed in the position. In either case, encourage students to bring statements made by Gov. Sarah Palin and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. from the debate and elsewhere to bear on their consideration of history, and vice versa.
Suggestion for a constitutional role focus:
Discuss with students how the vice president has been instrumental in United States history. Consider both the succession angle as well as the Senate presidency.
Questions to consider might include these: When has the vice president cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate? When has the very possibility that he could break a tie been decisive in Senate debates? Why do you think the framers of the Constitution granted the Senate presidency to the vice president? How many vice presidents have succeeded to the presidency mid-term? How many have been elected after the president with whom they served left office?
For more information on this topic, see the United States Senate Web site's page on the President of the Senate: .
Suggestion for a historical focus:
Discuss with students how the role of vice president has evolved throughout modern history. Provide John Nance Garner's oft-cited alleged quotation, "The vice presidency isn't worth a pitcher of warm spit," together with examples of modern vice presidents, such as Walter Mondale and Dick Cheney, who carved out more substantial roles in their administrations.
Questions to consider might include these: Based on the past eight years, with Mr. Cheney as vice president, what are your impressions of the office? What executive and advisory duties have vice presidents had in the past thirty or so years? What informal policy roles have recent vice presidents had? What do you imagine the relationships of presidents and vice presidents have been like over the years? Do you see an "active" vice president as a benefit to an administration or as a drawback? Why? Do you think the Constitution should be amended to provide the vice president with more explicit and expanded powers? Why or why not?
For more information on this topic, see the above Senate Web site as well as the following: The New York Times Multimedia Feature "When the Vice President Really Matters" (http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2008/09/07/weekinreview/20080907_VEEP_GRAPHIC.html); the New York Times book review "How the First Mate Shifted the Ship of State's Course" (http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/16/books/16kaku.html), and the Austin Statesman article "Throughout History, Vice Presidents Fumed as They Waited in the Wings" (http://www.statesman.com/opinion/content/editorial/stories/insight/08/03/0803veep.html). You may also play or have students listen to the NPR piece "The Evolving Role of the Vice President": http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=92705080.
Before continuing to the next activity, ask students how, if at all, this information might influence the ticket they support. Why?
Next, have students work in pairs or small groups, using all available resources, to complete the handout "The Role of Vice President" found at . In addition, based on the New York Times coverage of the vice presidential debates and other New York Times resources, have students fill in the handout "Senator Biden and Governor Palin on the Issues" found at . You may wish to have students complete this during the class period or as an ongoing assignment, as they learn more information about each running mate.
5. FOR HOMEWORK OR FUTURE CLASSES
After students have compiled a substantial amount of information on each vice presidential candidate's position on the issues, have them synthesize their findings in a persuasive essay, in support of one of the candidates. You may wish to offer the following prompts to guide them:

        
How does what you know now about the vice presidency and vice presidential history affect your decision to support this candidate?
        
In your opinion, what is the most important issue in this year's election, and how does this candidate's position relate to or reflect your stance?
        
What professional experience do you think this candidate lends to the ticket, and why?
        
What makes this person qualified to serve as first in line of succession to the president and to serve as president of the Senate, and why?
Students should take part in a peer editing session after their first essay drafts, and be evaluated based on their final essay.

Short article about the importance of the vice presidency this election season, written for high school students.Further Questions for Discussion:
- Why is the choice of vice president important? Support your answer with specifics.
- Do you believe that a presidential ticket should be "balanced" to reflect the demographics of the nation and/or to appeal to voters? Why or why not?
- Who do you think would make the ideal presidential and vice-presidential team? Support your answer.
- What personal qualities do you think should be important in considering the qualifications of a vice-presidential candidate? Consider marital status, family, race/ethnicity, religion, gender, age, professional and political experience, education, personality, personal history, etc. Why and how are these qualities important?
- How do you think you will be affected by the administration of whoever becomes vice president? Why?Vocabulary:
miscalibration, gaffe, quelling, sparred, repartee, onus, mien, condescension, maverick, symmetry, lamented, agile, riposte, veer.Extension Activities:
1. Write a memo to one of the presidential or vice-presidential candidates in which you provide constructive criticism on his or her debating strategy (based on this week's televised debate). Provide a thorough analysis of his or her presentation skills (including substance, oration, body language and tone), and make at least two recommendations.
2. Act as the moderator for a class debate on which ticket will make the better White House administration: Obama-Biden or McCain-Palin. Decide on the format and make a list of rules to govern the debate. You may want to consider the official debate format of the Commission on Presidential Debates (http://www.debates.org/pages/education.html#format). Then formulate 10 to 15 questions that cover the following five topics: the war in Iraq and Afghanistan; terrorism and national security; the economy; education; and the environment. If possible, stage the debate during a class period.
3. Choose a third-party vice-presidential candidate to research and write a biographical profile. Some third-party vice-presidential candidates include Matt Gonzalez (Independent), Darrell Castle (Constitution Party), Rosa Clemente (Green Party), Wayne Allyn Root (Libertarian Party), Frank McEnulty (Reform Party), Stewart Alexander (Socialist Party U.S.A.), Eugene Puryear (Party for Socialism and Liberation) and Alyson Kennedy (Socialist Workers Party).
4. Create a resume for your ideal candidate for the position of vice president of the United States. Be sure to include education, relevant experience and personal interests.Interdisciplinary Connections:
American History - Create a chart in which you compare the professional experience and campaign performance of vice presidents from the last five administrations. The chart should answer the following questions: How much political experience did each vice president have before taking office? What other kinds of experience did he or she have? Was the vice president initially running for president? Did he run for president after serving as vice president? If so, did he win? How did he perform in the vice presidential debate? Did he "win," "lose" or "tie"? Do experts believe he played a key role in the election?
        
Fine Arts- In recent times, presidential candidates have chosen campaign theme songs to reflect or represent their ideologies and plans for the future. Research the theme songs of the 2008 presidential candidates, and play clips of the songs for your class. Challenge your classmates to match the song to the candidate. Write a paragraph explaining whether the song reflects the party's election platform.
        
Journalism - Design and conduct a poll to gather information on the vice-presidential candidates in the 2008 election from classmates, neighbors and family members. Upon analyzing the results, which ticket do you feel has a better chance to win in your community? Report your findings in your school paper.Academic Content Standards:

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; OFF THE CHARTS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 577 words

HEADLINE: Pessimism About Jobs, Often a Recession Sign

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS. 
Floyd Norris comments on finance and economics in his blog at norris.blogs.nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AMERICANS have concluded that it is tough to get a job. That fact, along with a host of other issues, ranging from high gasoline prices to falling home prices and the credit crisis, provides reason to expect consumer spending to be weak.
 The belief that work is hard to find has typically become as widespread as it is now only many months after a recession has begun. In 2001, in fact, the view did not get that negative until after the recession was already over. 
 Worries about jobs often continue well after recessions end, a sign that the current sour outlook could continue for some time, even if the economy is close to hitting bottom.
 The figures on job market psychology are collected every month as part of the Conference Board's consumer confidence survey. Individuals are asked if jobs are plentiful, not so plentiful or hard to get. 
 The accompanying chart shows the net percentage of those who think jobs are plentiful less those who think they are hard to get. A number above zero shows that more think the job market is good than believe it to be bad. To smooth the numbers, the figures shown are three-month moving averages.
 In the preliminary September results, released this week, 12.2 percent thought jobs were plentiful and 32.8 percent thought they were hard to get. The 20.6 percentage point difference constitutes the worst job market perspective since late 2003.
 That figure has been getting worse at a rapid rate, so the three-month average is just a negative 18.5 percent. But that is still very low by standards of the last quarter-century. The figure was, however, much worse in the 1970s and early 1980s, when a series of recessions led to concern about prospects for the American economy.
 On Friday, the government reported that the unemployment rate remained at 6.1 percent in September but that the number of jobs fell 159,000 in the month. The survey was taken in the week that ended Sept. 12, just before the credit crisis intensified.
 ''It's the last snapshot of the economy before the credit crunch really hit,'' said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of ITG. He said the employment rate was likely to rise to 7 percent next year. 
 In the last two economic cycles, the recession was under way by the time more Americans thought jobs were hard to get than thought they were plentiful. This year, the figure turned negative in March, which would be consistent with a recession having started in late 2007.
 The other chart shows the percentage of respondents saying they expect to buy a car in the next six months. That figure, again on a three-month moving average, has fallen to 5 percent, the lowest figure since the Conference Board started asking the question in 1967.
 Detroit does not need to be told that polls show that auto buyers are reluctant; the carmakers reported very bad September sales this week.
 Typically, auto-buying intentions are slow to turn up until there is a better view of the job market, which implies a long period before revival.
 As the credit squeeze has intensified, many economic indicators have turned down. It now appears likely that the third quarter, which ended this week, will show a decline in gross domestic product, perhaps of 2 percent or even 3 percent at an annual rate. The government's first estimate of that figure will be released on Oct. 30, just five days before the presidential election, and it is unlikely to improve the outlook for auto sales or employment.

GRAPHIC: CHARTS: The job market looks bad . . .: Percentage of Americans who say jobs are plentiful minus those who say jobs are hard to get.
 . . . and so does the car market: Percentage of Americans who plan to buy a car within six months.(Source: Conference Board consumer confidence survey) Chart details line graphs for each category.

HEADLINE: What's On Today

BYLINE: By KATHRYN SHATTUCK

 BODY:
8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: PAUL HENREID Turner Classic Movies salutes Henreid, the actor and director who fled Nazi-occupied Europe during World War II to become a leading man at Warner Brothers. The five-film tribute begins with ''Now, Voyager'' (1942), starring Bette Davis as an ugly duckling who turns into a swan after falling in love with a married man (Henreid, above with Davis), at 8. Henreid also stars in ''The Spanish Main'' (1945) as a Dutch pirate in the Caribbean who kidnaps the Spanish governor's fiancee (Maureen O'Hara), at 10:15; ''Of Human Bondage'' (1946), as a medical student who risks his future when he becomes involved with a low-class waitress (Eleanor Parker), at midnight; ''Hollow Triumph'' (1948), as a gangster on the lam who poses as a psychiatrist, at 2 a.m.; and ''Casablanca'' (1942), at 3:30, in which Henreid plays the Czech resistance leader Victor Laszlo, a role he almost refused because he worried that playing second fiddle to Humphrey Bogart would tarnish his image -- even though he got the girl, played by Ingrid Bergman.
