HEADLINE: The Smart Money, Foiled Again

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM. 
Paul J. Lim is a senior editor at Money magazine. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com

 BODY:
SO far, the financial crisis on Wall Street has been as unpredictable as it's been severe. Consider some of the twists and turns we've already witnessed:
 A series of storied, blue-chip banks and brokerage firms with long track records of earnings growth suddenly collapse.
 The Dow plummets 777 points in a single day after one Wall Street bailout plan fails in the House of Representatives. And the Dow falls an additional 157 points on the day a second plan becomes law.
 Panicked investors renounce risk-taking, pushing the financial sector down by more than 20 percent since June. Yet there is enough of a gambling streak left to send shares of the perceived winners of this shake-up soaring, like Bank of America, up 54 percent; Wells Fargo, up 45 percent over the past three months; and JPMorgan Chase, up 30 percent. 
 It is hard to make sense of this market, which is precisely why you shouldn't assume that conventional wisdom is correct about how to play the crisis.
 The so-called smart money seems to avoiding three big investment categories: index funds, dividend-paying companies and small-caps. On paper, that seems to make perfect sense in these times. If you do a little homework, however, you will notice that some of these ideas haven't panned out. At least not yet. 
 TO INDEX OR NOT There is a simple reason for making the case that investing in index funds won't work in this crisis: Financial stocks represent one of the two biggest sectors in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, currently accounting for 16 percent of it.
 Actively managed funds would seem to have an advantage, since their managers have the freedom to step out of this losing sector and redeploy that money.
 That is the theory. In reality, most actively managed funds didn't have the foresight to avoid the meltdown in the financial sector. At the start of September, for example -- before the government's takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and its bailout of the American International Group -- the average actively managed large-cap fund invested nearly 15 percent of its assets in financial services. That was almost exactly the sector's weighting in the S.& P. 500 at the time.
 That may explain why active managers haven't been able to outperform basic index portfolios lately. Morningstar, the mutual fund tracker, did the calculations and found that the average large-cap index fund fell 26.8 percent over the past year through Sept. 29. That is almost the same as the 26.7 percent decline for actively managed large-cap funds. Over the past three years, their results were exactly the same: both active and index funds posted annualized losses of 2.2 percent.
 Among small-cap portfolios, index funds actually beat the average actively managed fund over the past year, three years and five years -- even though small-cap index funds maintain a far greater weighting in financial stocks than their actively managed counterparts.
 THE DIVIDEND QUESTION Financial stocks account for roughly a quarter of all the dividends paid out by the S.& P. 500 index, leading many people to say that investing in dividend-paying stocks isn't advisable now.
 As banks, brokers and insurers have run into hard times, many firms have cut or eliminated their dividends. This year, 30 financial companies in the S.& P. 500 have cut their payouts to the tune of $24.1 billion, according to Standard & Poor's.
 This certainly shows the dangers of betting on a handful of individual dividend-paying stocks. ''If you're trying to get income by owning just three or four high-yielders, you're taking a big risk that one or more will run into trouble,'' says Luciano Siracusano, director of research at WisdomTree asset management.
 But Mr. Siracusano noted that this doesn't mean that diversified dividend investing strategies will fail in this market.
 In fact, they are working. Not only did dividend-paying stocks in the S.& P. 500 beat non-dividend-payers in September -- the height of the financial crisis -- the dividend-payers have also outperformed over the past yearlong bear market. In the 12 months through September, around the market's peak, dividend-paying stocks have fallen 22.1 percent, versus a drop of 27.5 percent for nonpaying shares, according to Howard Silverblatt, S.& P.'s senior index analyst. 
 Some funds focus on dividend-paying stocks that have consistently raised their payouts, and these funds are performing particularly well. Consider the SPDR S.& P. Dividend E.T.F., an exchange-traded fund that tracks the S.& P. High Yield Dividend Aristocrats index. It includes only high-yielding stocks that have managed to raise dividends for 25 consecutive years, and it is down just 6.8 percent since the start of the year. Compare that with the 25.1 percent year-to-date loss for the S.& P. 500. 
 LARGE VS. SMALL STOCKS Many economists and market watchers believe the financial crisis will push the economy into a recession, if it's not already in one. ''I can't think of anyone who thinks there's not going to be a recession now,'' said Michael P. Balkin, co-manager of the William Blair Small Cap Growth fund. 
 If that is the case, the market could be in for a sustained period of volatility, which naturally drives investors to the safety of large, industry-leading companies. This may turn out to be the safest strategy. But here's a surprising twist: Since the middle of March, small-company stocks are holding their own. Since March 10, the Russell 2000 index of small stocks is down 3.7 percent.
 To be sure, small-cap stocks were punished in September, when the financial crisis really started to frighten the markets. But even then, small stocks lost 8 percent in the month, versus a drop of 9.5 percent for their large-cap cousins.
 EARLIER this year, the small caps' superior performance was regarded as a sign that this economic downturn might be short-lived. Today, few people think that the economy is on the verge of accelerating. But the real reason for this performance could be simpler than that: small-stock earnings have just held up better in this crisis.
 Steven G. DeSanctis, small-cap strategist at Merrill Lynch, noted in a recent report that small-cap earnings were expected to climb nearly 2 percent in the third quarter, versus an expected decline of 5 percent for the S.& P. 500. If this happens, it would be the fifth consecutive quarter when small-company earnings have held up better than those of large firms.
 Nevertheless, in the short term, small-cap stocks may not perform as well as they have recently, Mr. Balkin warned. ''They could just mark time, '' he said, especially if economic concerns come to the fore. But if the recession ends sometime in the first half, he said, 2009 could turn out to be a decent year for small stocks.

HEADLINE: For Two Longtime Bank Rivals in Charlotte, Competition Turns to Concern

BYLINE: By SHAILA DEWAN

 BODY:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- No sooner had construction begun in the late 1980s on the 42-story bank headquarters -- the tallest building in North Carolina -- than its biggest rival announced it would build a taller building right up the street.
If one bank gave $50,000 to the Chamber of Commerce, the other wrote a check for the same amount. When one built a performing arts center, the other built a museum. For decades here, it has been thus: the two banks, homegrown Wachovia and the larger Bank of America, gleefully one-upping each other, and Charlotte coming out the winner.
With Wachovia dominating the south end of Tryon Street, uptown's main thoroughfare, and Bank of America dominating the north end, Charlotte became the second-largest banking center in the nation, behind New York.
But last week, as Wachovia, which employs 20,000 people here, became the latest financial institution to succumb to the credit crisis, the long spirit of competition between the two banks swiftly turned to concern. 
''When you go to a boxing match, you want to win in the ring,'' said John Gachora, a managing director at Bank of America, ''not because all your opponents had a car crash on the way to the ring.''
With the financial crisis vividly in evidence, the mood on Tryon Street was palpably glum. Last weekend, after long hours of work trying to save Wachovia, one middle-aged employee had a fatal heart attack. In Raleigh, executives at RBC Bank canceled the parachuters that were supposed to appear at the grand opening of its new headquarters, saying it was not an appropriate time to have people jumping off a bank building.
Between the announcement on Monday that Wachovia would be forced to sell much of the company to Citigroup for an amount equal to $1 a share and the news on Friday of a more significant counteroffer from Wells Fargo, it has been a roller-coaster ride for the city. Even those who knew Wachovia was in trouble were shocked at the speed of its decline. At happy hour, the casual attire of those already laid off stood out against the dark suits of the still-employed but nervous. On Wednesday night Morton's, one of a herd of steakhouses catering to the banking crowd, was virtually empty.
Like many Wachovia shareholders, Tom Dunn, 64, who was a lawyer for Wachovia for years and is now at a law firm, was rethinking his retirement date after losing more than $1 million in Wachovia stock -- about half his savings. ''I'm very disappointed,'' Mr. Dunn said Wednesday. ''I'm telling myself that anger probably is not healthful.''
His disappointment was tempered a bit by the news about Wells Fargo -- long regarded as a better geographical match for Wachovia because it is based on the West Coast and could benefit from Wachovia's large East Coast footprint -- stepping in with a $7 a share offer. Citigroup is contesting the deal, and on Saturday night it said that a judge in New York issued an emergency order temporarily blocking the merger with Wells Fargo. Many in Charlotte have hopes that a sale to Wells Fargo would help preserve jobs.
Even if the jobs stay, said Bob Morgan, president of the Charlotte Chamber of Commerce, ''From a civic perspective, we can no longer walk across the street and see the C.E.O. of the fourth-largest bank in the country.''
The banks' respective territory is so jealously guarded that when Wachovia installed its first A.T.M. on the north end of Tryon Street, it was front-page news in The Charlotte Observer.
The two banks had different cultures. Wachovia, which started in Winston-Salem and was acquired by Charlotte's First Union in 2001, was regarded as a laid-back, collegial place where, even in this crisis, top-ranking executives have kept their jobs.
Bank of America, which has 13,000 employees here, is widely viewed as a more aggressive culture, flavored by the style of its longtime leader, Hugh L. McColl Jr., an ex-marine. ''My boss used to work at Bank of America,'' said a young Wachovia investment banker who declined to give his name because of insecurity about his job. ''She said she'd go in every day putting on her armor.''
But social life was a different story. Wachovia and Bank of America executives live in the same neighborhoods, their children go to the same schools and their junior associates frequent the same uptown bars.
On Tuesday Robert Stickler, a senior vice president at Bank of America, said a Wachovia executive would be joining his family for Rosh Hashana dinner. ''In business they were very fierce competitors, but that ended when the business day ended,'' Mr. Stickler said. ''There's a lot of concern inside our headquarters over the last couple of days because a lot of us have friends at Wachovia. They were working as hard as we were, they just made a bad decision.''
When the banks were smaller, their contest was fiercer, said George V. Hanna III, a lawyer at Moore & Van Allen and a longtime Charlotte resident. ''If you were for one, you were against the other,'' Mr. Hanna said. ''It was very difficult for providers of professional services like law firms to work for both of them. As the banks got larger, the competition within Charlotte lessened.''
Both viewed Charlotte as an important investment. Led by the banks, the city poured money into sports facilities and graceful streetscaping, making Charlotte -- the largest city in North Carolina -- a magnet for young college-educated professionals and keeping its real estate market strong even as the rest of the country suffered.
When the forced sale of Wachovia was announced Monday, Mr. McColl, who is no longer with Bank of America, called it ''a body blow'' to the city.
Everywhere, the conversation centered on the details of the sale. Would the buyer retain Wachovia's name, with its reputation for sterling customer service, or jettison it as tainted by financial failure? Would the retail banking division stay in Charlotte?
What would happen to the new Wachovia tower, with its state-of-the-art trading floors, under construction on South Tryon Street, and the arts complex that was part of the project? ''The cranes are still working,'' said Micheal Shook, who works at an agency that provides staff for the two banks.
The uncertainty was not limited to the south end of Tryon. Bank of America is also in flux after its purchase of Merrill Lynch last month, prompting worries that much of the company's investment banking would move to New York. A significant drain of financial jobs from the city would affect real estate values, recruitment, support companies like law and accounting firms and other issues that have a bearing on both banks.
One executive at Bank of America said the mood was evident when he announced that he would be leaving for another job.
''If I went last year to resign, my boss would have said, 'What can I do to get you to stay?' '' he said, declining to use his name because he was quoting another employee. Instead, his boss told him, ''I want you to stay, but congratulations, because I don't even know if I'll be here myself.''

 Wachovia, also in Charlotte, succumbed to the credit crisis. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JASON MICZEK/REUTERS) (pg.A35)

HEADLINE: Boswell to the Bluebloods

BYLINE: By CAROLINE H. DWORIN

 BODY:
EACH morning, David Patrick Columbia looks online to check the price of gold. Then he reads the financial pages in newspapers here and abroad. He reads The Financial Times, The Guardian and The Telegraph. He reads Page Six of The New York Post; he reads the obituaries. 
 For a self-made social chronicler of the city's ruling set, its socialites and its power brokers, all this reading serves to indicate how his work will proceed. 
 Now, with a nation mired in financial ambiguity, eyes turn to the very well-to-do for some hint of what lies ahead. And the very well-to-do are a demographic that Mr. Columbia has watched and studied and documented for many years. 
 His signature New York Social Diary began in 1993 as a monthly society column in Quest magazine, a publication for the city's upper crust, and in 2000 made its first appearance online as an independent project. In the diary, with the help of his business partner, Jeffrey Hirsch, Mr. Columbia combines society pages with personal reflection, resulting in an often giddy, celebratory chronicle of galas in gilded ballrooms, opening nights at the opera and annual picnics on Long Island lawns. 
 This first-person essay offers a remarkable portrait of what it was like to be present at the dawn of the millennium, as the stock charts peaked, trembled and plunged, and as the drinks flowed on late into the night, before the party ended. 
 At 6 feet 4 inches, Mr. Columbia stands out in a crowd. Well dressed, with light hair parted at the side, and round glasses, he displays a courteous curiosity that draws secrets from socialites' lips. He listens intensely. But when he speaks, his eyes widen, his eyebrows rise, and his long-fingered hands sketch images in the air; he conducts conversation as one might conduct an orchestra. 
 His Web site bristles with society news beneath a blue, white and fuchsia header that is flanked by high-rent advertisements (Diane von Furstenberg, Bergdorf Goodman). Prose is punctuated by photographs: little groups of smiling socialites caught cocktail in hand for a frozen moment, the light of the flash touching golden brocade, a diamond earring, the chalk-white teeth of a smiling tycoon. Last month, on Mr. Columbia's calendar: a post-symphony dinner in a tent next to the Metropolitan Opera; a gala at Cipriani for New Yorkers for Children; names like Muffie Potter Aston, Whitney Fairchild and Bronson Van Wyck, echoes of stately Old World class. 
 ''No, I am not Gatsby,'' Mr. Columbia once said of himself. ''I'm Nick Carraway. I live in the little house next door.''
 In recent weeks, as financial fears trump a presidential election, reporters from news organizations like Reuters and The Los Angeles Times have contacted Mr. Columbia to see what he could tell them about how the crisis has affected New York's rich. 
 ''What these people are asking is what has happened,'' he said. ''What has happened? Nothing had happened. It's too soon to determine what's happened.'' 
 Yet his tone between parties grows grim. ''Financial stress in a community, if widespread enough,'' he wrote after Congress initially voted down an economic bailout, ''can be like spilled gasoline and easily ignite.''
 One evening in late September, Mr. Columbia attended a dinner party with a number of extremely rich guests who had suddenly lost a good deal of their assets. 
 ''The conversation went on about the summer,'' he said, ''about the children, about travel. Actually, no one was talking about it. They really don't know how to even assimilate that information.'' His loud, clear voice deepened: ''We have been drinking champagne for a long time.''
 ON a Wednesday in August, when many of those who make things happen in New York were in the Hamptons or abroad, Mr. Columbia, wearing a seersucker blazer with four cream-colored buttons at each cuff, took lunch at Michael's, the celebrated restaurant on West 55th Street, just off Fifth Avenue. 
 Mr. Columbia keeps a table on the periphery, at once a part of the fray and removed from it. 
 Across the room, a gentleman with a thick head of white hair raised his hand to Mr. Columbia, who waved back. ''That's Harry Benson,'' he said. ''He's taken some of the most iconic photographs of our age.
 ''Bill Rondina,'' he said, peering around at the tables. ''He owns a company called Carlisle, which sells women's clothing.'' Regulars include the billionaire Ronald Perelman, Barbara Walters and the gossip columnist Liz Smith.
 A woman from Sotheby's paused to chat; a man invited him to spend a weekend at his house in Bridgehampton; hardly a diner passed by without stopping at his table to shake his hand or touch his arm. 
 But between pleasant pockets of small talk, Mr. Columbia spoke of financial turmoil, and how we all got ourselves into this mess. In this credit card era, he sees a nation and its people mistaking debt for money, with no idea of the consequences.
 ''That's a phenomenon in our society,'' he said, ''of people just standing facing danger and not moving. I remember the footage I saw of the tsunami, of people standing on a hillside watching it at the ocean's edge, and they were startled and astonished and amazed. And then the ocean came and took them all away. They didn't know how to get out of the way.'' 
 Several weeks later, the federal government took control of the nation's two largest mortgage lenders, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac; Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy; the Fed loaned $85 billion to American International Group; and Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson proposed a $700 billion life raft to save a sinking financial system.
 ''We are about to go from adolescence to adulthood,'' Mr. Columbia had said that summer day at lunch. ''The way the American people have been living for the last 25 years -- some say it's going to come to a crashing end.'' He smiled and picked up his spoon. ''I don't mean to be apocalyptic.''
 THE funny thing about The New York Social Diary is that no one seems to read it. ''Oh, yes, I've been in it,'' a woman at a party said. ''Three times, I've been told.'' 
 Nevertheless, the site is visited by some 600,000 individual users every month; regular readers are those featured in its pages: business leaders, philanthropists and socialite doyennes. Then there's a toll clerk named Mahogany, who writes from her booth in Houston, commenting on the dresses and the hair, curious to know if Muffie Potter Aston is still married to that doctor.
 In addition to the diary, for which Mr. Columbia produces all the content, and the photographs, most of which are taken by Mr. Hirsch, who works from his loft across town, the site includes sections on travel, philanthropy, shopping and art.
 In the House column, the writer-designer team of Sian Ballen and Lesley Hauge conduct interviews in subjects' homes, perched side by side with a tape recorder, as Mr. Hirsch roams about shooting pictures. 
 Guest diarists contribute their own memories. Peter Evans, a journalist and biographer, wrote: ''Christina Onassis once told me that she wore diamonds at breakfast because 'they look so pretty in the morning sun. You have no idea how erotic men find dew on the rocks.' '' 
 But along with its photos, The New York Social Diary is best known for Mr. Columbia's effervescent musings on the city's bold-faced names. 
 ''Around two, two-thirty ayem,'' Mr. Columbia wrote not long ago, ''they were setting up for the breakfast menu although by 3 o'clock in the morning, the crowd had begun to thin out, heading back to their lairs high above the canyons of Manhattan, done in, sated, satisfied and ready to lay their little heads down for some sleepy time. The boy from South Africa who came to the Big Town quite some time ago to make his fortune, had ushered in his 7th decade (the 7th decade begins at age six-oh) with a big bang and a good time to be had by all. It'll be a while before he one-ups himself after this one.''
 The Web site Gawker once described Mr. Columbia as its ''favorite sycophant diarist,'' mocking him for suggesting that ''The Real Housewives of New York'' were not real Society (capital ''S''), when his own father was a chauffeur. 
 Mr. Columbia had written: ''An expensive apartment, a limo and a house in the Hamptons does not society make.'' And he stood by it, never claiming to want any social status but his own.
 ''If you hang out with a bunch of champion tennis players, it doesn't make you a champion tennis player,'' he said. ''It's the same with society. You don't get it by declaring, 'I am.' ''
 Among those who criticize him for pandering to the upper class is Remy Stern, the creator of Cityfile.com -- a ''Zagat's guide to people,'' as he describes the site -- who considers The New York Social Diary too gentle and too polite. ''Younger people,'' Mr. Stern said, ''are less inclined to be interested in very fluffy editorial.''
 Yet, more sociologist than sycophant, a writer and student of the game of power, Mr. Columbia has little patience for snark.
 ''I'm very interested in extracting what it is like if you are really there,'' he said. ''What it feels like. And often it doesn't feel like anything.''
 WERE he to print all he knew, all he had witnessed of the nature of power, he might not be invited to so many parties. He remembers once, at a summer wedding, seeing a young guest kneeling beside the chair where his father-in-law sat. The two men spoke quietly together, after which the older man removed a fist-size wad of cash from his pocket and handed it to the son-in-law. Mr. Columbia watched the young man's face. 
 ''Wide-eyed lust,'' he remembers. ''Almost a sexual lust. I never wanted that money.'' Nor the things it could buy. ''I don't want the house. I've seen that house, I know that house, I've been inside that house, I've danced in that house.''
 David Patrick Columbia grew up in a little house in Westfield, Mass., in the foothills of the Berkshires. His father was the chauffeur for ''Black Jack'' Bouvier, the wild, womanizing father of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. These were the upstairs people. ''We were downstairs people,'' Mr. Columbia said. 
 His father gambled, and as a result, his mother, an industrious, creative woman, had to work. His older sisters left when he was small, so it was he who listened: When she cried over the sink washing dishes, he was there. ''That was kind of an onus, in a way,'' he said of her suffering. ''But the reality was it strengthened her. Growing up with this woman who was very, very unhappy about her life made a very deep impression on this little boy.'' 
 His parents argued constantly, and perhaps the only thing that soothed their quarrels was their intimate, involved discussions about the exotic lives of the ''upstairs people'' that theirs just grazed. David listened in on these fairy tales, and they soothed him, too. He asked for, and was given, a typewriter and a dollhouse.
 Over the years, Mr. Columbia moved through many phases, many careers. He was married for nine years, divorcing to pursue a relationship with a man; and for a time in the 1970s he owned a head shop in the Westchester town of Pound Ridge. He spent 14 years in Los Angeles, writing anything he could, then collaborated with Debbie Reynolds on ''Debbie: My Life,'' her 1988 memoir. 
 In 1992, he began writing society profiles for Quest magazine, a looking-glass for Manhattan's well-to-do. Mr. Columbia, it seemed, could don a well-tailored suit and fit into whatever environment he chose. He remembers what his mother used to say, a fleck of envy in her voice: ''You always thought you could do anything.''
 Since 1996, he has lived in a modest one-bedroom rental on the Upper East Side, with a balcony overlooking East End Avenue. The place is packed with books and photographs -- Mr. Columbia with childhood friends, Mr. Columbia as a little boy outside his sister's high school, Mr. Columbia smiling next to Hillary Rodham Clinton, Mr. Columbia smiling next to the Dalai Lama -- and two excitable Shih Tzus named Missy and Byron. 
 One afternoon, wearing blue jeans and loafers, he stood in his nook of a kitchen cutting up chicken for the dogs.
 ''I have a lot of opinions about a lot of things,'' Mr. Columbia said. ''And a lot of insight into a lot of things. I don't really comment on a lot of things. Because my responsibility is to leave a record of what it appears to be like at the scene. I can't tell you what that will mean later on.''
 THE benefit last month shut down 73rd Street between Lexington and Third Avenues at rush hour, drew hundreds of people and encased the street in a party tent hung with sequined apple-shaped ornaments. At the entrance to the tent, a woman painted teal and dressed as the Statue of Liberty posed for photographs as white-coated waiters shuttled drinks and hors d'oeuvres.
 This was the fifth year of the Fete de Swifty, a fund-raiser named for a restaurant named for a dog. Last year, the event raised about $750,000 for the Mayor's Fund to Advance New York City, with the money going to a program that fights domestic abuse. 
 When Mr. Columbia arrived, late, wearing a blue jacket with gold buttons, a blue shirt and a butter-colored tie, two middle-aged women called to him in little-girl voices. They toyed with their hair, adjusted their dresses and posed. He took their picture. Others approached: couples, groups, all of them kissing his cheek and touching his arm, sharing details of their lives, and asking after his.
 ''He thinks he knows the A-list,'' said Joseph Fichera, the chief executive officer of a financial advisory firm on Wall Street, as Mr. Columbia passed with an elegant mob. ''Actually, I think he makes the A-list.''
 A young blond woman who worked at Sotheby's stumbled about on the arm of a friend. A dark-haired woman sat alone with a drink, opening fortune cookies one at a time.
 ''I have to go stand up there with him,'' Mr. Columbia said with a sigh as Mayor Bloomberg took the stage. Disengaging himself from the throng, he made his way to those gathered for a group photo with the mayor, who had reminded the guests of the need for philanthropy, that ''not everyone is as lucky as us.''
 Cameras flashed, lighting lavish clothes and perfect hair. When they stopped, the group broke up, and the stage was quickly dismantled.

HEADLINE: Through a Financial Wringer Sept. 28-Oct. 4

 BODY:
THE NEWS The House of Representatives unexpectedly rejects the $700 billion economic rescue plan negotiated by the leaders of both parties, the Treasury and the White House. 
 BEHIND THE NEWS Efforts by central banks before the vote to loosen up straitened credit markets with big injections of cash fell flat, so when the bill's defeat becomes clear, stock markets spiral downward; the Dow industrials fall nearly 7 percent, their worst day in decades. The defeat reflects broad public anger over the rescue package, which is criticized as an undeserved bailout of Wall Street high-flyers. House Republicans, in particular, defy their leaders to vote no. 
 THE NEWS A day of behind-the-scenes scrambling in Washington yields a new version of the rescue package for the Senate to consider, with added provisions like tax breaks for businesses and alternative energy and an expansion of deposit-insurance coverage. 
 BEHIND THE NEWS The additions to the bill are meant to make it more politically palatable, but they promise to add billions to the cost of the rescue package while adding little to its effectiveness. Equity investors are relieved at the progress, and major stock indexes retrace about half of Monday's losses. But nervous banks are still reluctant to lend either to customers or one another, and credit markets remain tight.
 THE NEWS The Senate approves the revised rescue bill by a comfortable 75-24 margin. 
 BEHIND THE NEWS Signs of worsening problems in the broader economy begin to pile up, as a political consensus gathers around the revised plan. Automakers report double-digit percentage falls in sales; an index of manufacturing activity deteriorates; and a major injection of capital into General Electric by the billionaire investor Warren Buffett fails to buoy its shares. After sliding in the morning, major stock indexes climb back to roughly where they started the day. But little relief is seen in credit markets, prompting calls for more coordinated action by central banks. 
 THE NEWS Though both the European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve signal that they are giving new consideration to interest-rate cuts, neither takes action on rates. 
 BEHIND THE NEWS Mounting anxiety about the economy sends stock indexes tumbling again, while party leaders in Washington try to wrangle enough votes in the House to pass the revised rescue bill. Ripple effects of the continuing constriction of credit are seen in the insurance industry, state and municipal finance, construction, Silicon Valley and other sectors afield from Wall Street. One silver lining of sorts for consumers: The prospect of withering demand pushes oil prices down.
 THE NEWS The House of Representatives passes the revised rescue package by a comfortable margin, and President Bush quickly signs it into law. 
 BEHIND THE NEWS The sweeteners added to the bill win over some opponents, though more Republicans still vote no than yes. Stocks rally strongly before the vote but slump afterward, as investors turn attention to a gloomy employment report and to the specter of a legal battle over the fate of Wachovia, a major bank. The credit markets stay frozen, awaiting the implementation of the rescue plan; though officials promise quick action, experts say it will be weeks before the Treasury can actually start buying up troubled assets.

 MANUEL BALCE CENETA/ASSOCIATED PRESS CENTER)
